qas.question: What year was the Olympic Games apparatus and events standardized?
Who set the first precedent that continues this day?
Who recieved the first perfect score?
What year and where was the first perfect score given?

answers.text: 1976 Summer Olympics held in Montreal, Canada

qas.question: When did men and women start wearing matching uniforms?
Who wanted the Olympic games to be held every year?
What medium gave gymnasts a bad reputation?
Who received a perfect score at the 1980 Olympics?
Who was the first gymnastics judge?

context: By <a0_0><b5_0>1954<b5_0/><a0_0/>, Olympic Games apparatus and events for both men and women had been standardized in modern format, and uniform grading structures (including <a1_0>a point system from 1 to 15<a1_0/>) had been agreed upon. At this time, <a2_0><b6_0>Soviet gymnasts<b6_0/><a2_0/> astounded the world with highly disciplined and difficult performances, setting a precedent that continues. The new medium of <b7_0>television<b7_0/> has helped publicize and initiate a modern age of gymnastics. Both men's and women's gymnastics now attract considerable international interest, and excellent gymnasts can be found on every continent. <a3_0><b8_0>Nadia Comăneci<b8_0/><a3_0/> received the first perfect score, at the <a4_0>1976 Summer Olympics held in Montreal, Canada<a4_0/>. She was coached in Romania by coach, (Hungarian ethnicity), <b9_0>Béla Károlyi<b9_0/>. Comaneci scored four of her perfect tens on the uneven bars, two on the balance beam and one in the floor exercise. Even with Nadia's perfect scores, the Romanians lost the gold medal to the Soviet Union. Nevertheless, Comaneci became an Olympic icon.
